Graphical abstract The effect of promoting a 15wt.% Ni/Al2O3 catalyst with small amounts of Mo (0.1 and 0.5wt.%) to produce H2 via propane oxidative steam reforming was investigated. Activity and stability experiments run at 450°C showed that the 0.1wt.% Mo-promoted catalyst had higher propane conversion, higher H2 yields and showed superior performance in terms of resisting deactivation by coking. Different characterization techniques show that the impact on activity, selectivity and stability are driven by an electronic effect of Mo on Ni, even with such small amounts. For example, oxygen storage capacity measurements revealed higher oxygen mobility over the promoted catalyst surface. This high O2 mobility led to higher gasification rates of carbonaceous species, leading to higher H2 yields and preventing coking of the catalyst. In-situ DRIFTS experiments also showed that the addition of Mo affected the stability of adsorbed reaction intermediates on the catalyst surface. Higher CO yields over the Mo-promoted catalyst resulted from weak adsorption or rapid desorption of CO in the presence of these small amounts of Mo. These changes in intermediate species stabilities affected some pathways in the general propane oxidative steam reforming scheme. Weak adsorption of CO also decreased the amount further oxidized to CO2 while the increased oxidation of CHx species lowered the amount hydrogenated to CH4. Keywords Hydrogen production Steam reforming Ni-Mo catalysts 1 Introduction Because of its common storage and existing infrastructure, propane is a potential candidate as a hydrogen carrier. Early studies included research on total combustion and during the 1990s significant amounts of research were published which focused on propane reforming (mainly steam reforming) as a process to supply hydrogen [1]. Autothermal reforming has also been investigated, where the reactor combines endothermic steam reforming with exothermic oxidation reactions, via the addition of small amounts of O2 [2]. For many years, nickel has been the most suitable metal for steam reforming of propane as far as cost effectiveness is concerned. Usually nickel is supported on alumina, magnesia, zirconia and/or ceria [3–6]. These supports provide high crush strength and stability. However, coke formation is still a major problem associated with nickel catalysts. Filamentous carbon is formed at the surface of the metal particle by consecutive formation, diffusion and dissolution of carbon [7]. As the coke is produced, the degradation of the catalyst is accelerated until the catalyst is deactivated by coking and continuation of catalyzed reforming becomes impossible. To improve the stability of the Ni-based catalyst and its resistance to coking, many researchers have considered adding another metal to Ni to form a bimetallic structure on the same support, as well as adding small amounts of O2 to be fed with steam and propane [8–12]. The benefit of adding a metal to a monometallic catalyst is driven by the structural interaction between the two metals, or between the metals and the support within the new bimetallic catalyst. Generally, these structural interactions may be of a textural nature affecting the physical properties of the Ni catalyst such as metal dispersion or metal crystal surface area [13–15] or they may be of an electronic nature, changing electronic densities of different catalyst components, and hence affecting the adsorption and chemical interactions of these components with different reaction intermediates [16,17]. Although these interactions may be established at the onset of the reaction [4,6,18,19], the nature of these interactions may change during time on stream. Mo-Ni catalysts have been extensively studied in the literature as active and stable hydrodesulphurization catalysts [20,21]. In these catalyst formulations, the Mo loading is greater than that of Ni, since Mo is the primary desulphurization metal, while Ni is added as a promoter. More recently, a number of studies have evaluated Ni-Mo catalysts for reactions other than desulphurization, especially those that have Ni as the main reactant-activation metal [22–27]. Although in most of these studies the resistance of Ni-Mo catalysts to coking during hydrocarbon reforming has been observed, an agreed upon explanation of the role of Mo has not been established, especially for very low Mo loadings (<0.5wt.%) [16,17]. Moreover, in many studies the addition of Mo to Ni had a negative impact on catalyst activity [28–30], while none discussed the effect of Ni-Mo catalysts on the selectivity to different steam reforming (SR) or oxidative steam reforming (OSR) reaction products. The objective of this study was to investigate the effect of adding small amounts of Mo to a 15wt.% Ni/Al2O3 propane reforming catalyst. Different characterization techniques were applied to understand the nature of the effects (textural and electronic) with the addition of small amounts of Mo (0.1–1wt.%) on the Ni catalyst, and to explain the changes and improvements in the catalytic properties based on these. 2 Experimental methods The 15wt.% Ni/Al2O3 (15Ni) catalyst was prepared using a wet impregnation method. A calculation using the support surface area and Ni atomic radius suggests that 15wt.% is the amount of Ni required to form a monolayer of the support surface. Commercial γ-Al2O3, in the form of a 3 micron powder, with a surface area of 80–120m2/g and 99.97% metal basis, was purchased from Alfa Aesar. After drying the required amount of support overnight, the calculated amount of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, used as the Ni precursor (also obtained from Alfa Aesar), was added to the Al2O3 powder and mixed in deionized water. After mixing, water was evaporated by heating and stirring the mixture until a paste-like mixture was obtained. The paste was dried overnight, and then the catalyst was crushed and sieved to obtain 35-45 mesh particles. The 15wt.% Ni-X wt.% Mo/γ-Al2O3 bimetallic catalyst was prepared using a co-impregnation method. In this method, (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O (supplied by Alfa Aesar) was used as the Mo precursor, and was dissolved with the Ni(NO3)2·6H2O. Following the same evaporation and drying procedure of the 15Ni catalyst, 35–45 mesh particles of the bimetallic catalyst were obtained. The freshly prepared catalysts were then calcined at 700°C for 3h. Three Mo-based samples were prepared: 15wt.% Ni–0.1wt.% Mo/γ-Al2O3 (0.1Mo), 15wt.% Ni–0.5wt.% Mo/γ-Al2O3 (0.5Mo) and 15wt.% Ni-1wt.% Mo/γ-Al2O3 (1Mo, which was used only in TPR experiments). H2-TPR experiments were run using a 0.3mm ID quartz reactor, filled with 200mg from the same catalyst batches, after calcination in the furnace with air circulation for 3h at 700°C. The temperature was ramped from room temperature to 950°C at a rate of 3°C/min. At 300°C a stream of 5% H2 in N2 was introduced. H2O produced via the reduction was removed using a silica gel trap before reaching the GC. H2 concentrations were measured using an Agilent 3000 micro GC equipped with a TCD. XRD patterns were compared for the non-promoted 15Ni catalyst and two Mo-promoted catalysts; 0.1Mo and 0.5Mo. XRD patterns were measured first for fresh catalysts after calcination in an external oven at 700°C, and then after reduction by H2 at 750°C. Also, in order to identify patterns resulting from the support, XRD patterns were obtained from pure γ-Al2O3 calcined at 700°C. A BrukerAXS D8 Advance diffractometer using a Bragg-Brentano geometry with Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation of λ =1.5425Å was used. Spectra were collected for a 2θ range of 15–80° using a step size of 0.02° and a count time of 1 second. H2 chemisorption was measured for three reduced catalysts (15Ni, 0.1Mo and 0.5Mo) to calculate Ni dispersions as well as Ni crystallite size. Measurements were performed in a Hiden CatLab reactor using a dynamic flow technique to measure H2 chemisorption uptake at room temperature. Prior to each run the catalyst was reduced under a H2 stream at 750°C. The reactor was then cooled down under He and pulses of a H2/He stream were injected through the catalyst bed. H2 uptakes were measured using a Hiden QIC mass spectrometer until no further H2 uptake was detected. Oxygen storage capacity (OSC) measurements were performed in a Hiden CatLab reactor. 50mg of fresh pre-calcined catalyst at 700°C for 3h was placed in a tube reactor of 4mm ID. The catalyst was first reduced in a 5% H2 in He stream at 750°C for 30min. Then the temperature was cooled to room temperature and the reactor was flushed with pure He. A dynamic flow technique was used to measure O2 uptake at room temperature. In this method, pulses of a 1vol% O2/He were injected through the catalyst bed and O2 uptakes were measured using a Hiden QIC mass spectrometer until no further O2 uptake was detected. The same procedure was repeated to measure O2 uptake at 400°C. In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) experiments were performed in a Nicolet Nexus spectrometer, equipped with a MCT detector and a KBr beam splitter. 100mg of pre-reduced powder catalyst was placed in a small cylindrical ceramic cell. The maximum cell temperature that could be reached was 400°C, controlled using a Thermo ScientificCal 9500P temperature controller. Prior to each run, background normalization of the spectra was performed by subtracting the spectrum recorded in a flow of He at the reaction temperature. In all experiments, the spectra were averaged over 50 scans in the mid IR range (600–4000cm−1) to a nominal 4cm−1 resolution. Scans were taken every minute until no change between spectra was observed. The reaction gases were then stopped and only He was flowed as desorption spectra were collected. Spectra were collected and analyzed using OMNIC computer software. Activity and selectivity of different catalysts for propane steam reforming were tested in a standard laboratory fixed bed reactor setup composed of three main parts; the reactant delivery system, the reactor and the analytical system. Gases were supplied by Praxair. Propane had a quality grade of 99.5%, with a sulfur content less than 1 ppmw, while O2, H2 and N2 had quality grades of 99.99%. Flow rates of the different gases were controlled by mass flow controllers. A Brooks 5850E mass flow controller was used to control the flow rate of propane, while Unit UFC 1000 mass controllers were used to control flow rates of the other gases. The specified amount of steam was generated by delivering deionized water to a vaporizer through a KDS model 200 syringe pump manufactured by KD Scientific. The vaporizer consists of an 18″ long, 1/8″ OD stainless steel tube, wrapped in heating tape. To ensure complete vaporization of the water, the vaporizer temperature was set and maintained at 230°C. The gases mix with steam in the vaporizer before entering the reactor from the top. The reactor was installed inside a vertical tube furnace and consisted of a quartz tube 555mm long with an ID of 9.9mm and wall thickness of 2mm, where the catalyst bed sat on a quartz frit located 220mm from the top of the reactor, in the middle of the isothermal zone of the reactor. A K-type thermocouple was installed inside the furnace, just beside the catalyst bed, to control the furnace temperature, while the catalyst bed temperature was measured using a quartz sheathed micro K-type thermocouple located just above the bed. The hot product stream entered a condenser, where the water was removed. The non-condensable gas products exited the condenser to the GC for compositional analysis. The effluent gases from the reactor were analyzed using a Varian CP3800 GC. The GC was fitted with two separation columns. Light gases, H2, O2, N2, CO, CH4 and CO2, were separated through a 15′×1/8″ stainless steel 60/80 mesh Carboxen 1000 column (spherical carbon molecular sieve partials, Supelco Inc.) connected to a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The other column was a 50m×0.53mm Al2O3/KCl fused silica PCOT column (Varian Inc.) connected to a flame ionization detector (FID) used to separate light hydrocarbons (C1 to C3). The analysis was performed simultaneously by two parallel injections through two injection valves. In addition to the two columns, a 2′ porapak N pre-column was used to hold hydrocarbons larger than CH4 and prevent them from reaching the Carboxen column. These hydrocarbons therefore do not affect the separation of the light gasses and this also reduces the analysis time. To elute the different gases in a discernible and timely manner, a temperature program was employed for the GC oven that contains both columns. Using this system a product sample was analyzed every 23min. The activity performances were compared based on the total conversion of propane calculated for each GC injection as: (1) Propane conversion % = moles of propane in − moles of propane out moles of propane in × 100 The catalyst selectivity to the four main propane steam reforming products (H2, CO, CO2 and CH4) was compared in terms of product yield. The yield of a product Y P was defined as: (2) Y P = n p n p r o p × X p r o p where n p is the product molar flow rate (mol/min), n prop is the propane feed molar flow rate (mol/min), and X prop is the propane conversion The steam to carbon ratio, S/C, in the feed was defined as: (3) S C = moles of steam fed into the reactor 3 × moles of propane fed The oxygen to carbon ratio (O2/C) in the feed was defined as: (4) O 2 C = moles of oxygen fed into the reactor 3 × moles of propane fed The carbon balance for a GC injection was calculated as: (5) C b a l a n c e = 3 × n p r o p a n e o u t + n CO o u t + n CO 2 o u t + n CH 4 o u t 3 × n p r o p a n e i n × 100 where n j is the number of moles of gas j. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst activity tests Catalyst activity tests for propane SR were compared for three catalysts: the non-promoted 15% Ni/Al2O3 (15Ni) and two Mo-promoted catalysts, 0.1% Mo–15% Ni/Al2O3 (0.1Mo) and 0.5% Mo–15% Ni/Al2O3 (0.5Mo). Propane conversion and catalyst selectivity to different products were compared for the three catalysts at 450°C, for a steam-to-carbon (S/C) of 3 and a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 339,800ml/hgcat. Prior to each run the catalyst was reduced in-situ at 750°C for 30min in a 10vol% H2/N2 mixture, then cooled to 450°C in flowing N2. Conversion as a function of time is shown in Fig. 1 , while H2 yields are compared in Fig. 2 . Experiments were repeated to ensure reproducibility of the data and errors are reported. Throughout the 6h run, the 0.1Mo catalyst sustained the highest conversion, 76%. A much lower conversion, 50%, was observed for 0.5Mo catalyst. The un-promoted catalyst attained approximately 70% conversion in the first hour, but did not sustain its activity; the conversion decreased gradually with time to reach 59% towards the end of the run. H2 yields were higher over the Mo catalysts, with the 0.5Mo catalyst having a higher H2 yield than 0.1Mo. The same trends were observed for CO yields for the three catalysts, as shown in Fig. 3 . In fact, the 0.5Mo catalyst had much higher CO yields than the other two catalysts. Also, temperature profiles of all catalyst beds during the reaction showed temperature decreased through the bed, even with the substantial silicon carbide dilution, because of the endothermic reaction. This extent of temperature change followed: 0.5Mo (14°C)>0.1Mo (12°C)>15Ni (8°C). The higher decrease in bed temperatures and higher syngas yields over Mo catalysts indicate higher steam reforming rates. The 0.5Mo catalyst showed lower CO2 yields, while the other two had higher yields with no significant differences between them (Fig. 4 ). Both Mo-promoted catalysts showed lower CH4 yields compared to the un-promoted catalyst (Fig. 5 ). During steam reforming reactions CH4 is produced via propane hydrogenolysis [31]: (R1) C3H8 +H2 →C2H6 +CH4 Or carbon gasification by H2: (R2) C+2H2 ↔CH4 C2H6 was not detected in significant amounts for any of the reactions, and therefore it is unlikely that CH4 was produced by Reaction R1. The production of CH4 by the gasification Reaction (R2) is also not favored under our conditions, because gasification of C by O2 or H2O has a higher rate than gasification by H2 [32]. A third common source for CH4 in SR reactions is the methanation reaction, which is actually the reverse of CH4 steam reforming. (R3) CO+3H2 =CH4 +H2O The mirror image observed when comparing Fig. 5, CH4 yields, to Fig. 3, CO yields, over the three catalysts suggests that Mo-promoted catalysts do not favor the methanation reaction, leading to lower CH4 yields and higher syngas yields. This was evaluated by running separate experiments for CH4 production via the methanation reaction over the 15Ni and the 0.1Mo catalysts, since they had higher activities than 0.5Mo. Experiments were run at the same temperature and GHVS as the reforming tests, and introducing CO and H2 at a ratio of 0.5 CO/H2. Production rates for the products at steady state from these runs are presented in Table 1 . These results show that Mo-promoted catalysts actually did not have a significant effect on the methanation reaction that may have explained low CH4 production rates over these catalysts. The reason will ultimately be discussed in Section 3.3, where the role of Mo is attributed to preventing the complete dehydrogenation of CHx species and directly oxidizing them to CO and H2. At the end of each run, the catalyst bed was cooled under N2 and was weighed. The catalyst bed weight of the 15Ni catalyst increased by 30%, via the formation of carbon, which was visually observed over the catalyst, and this carbon formation would lead to activity loss. The 0.1Mo catalyst bed weight increased by 6% with no visually obvious carbon, while the 0.5 Mo catalyst did not show any change in the bed weight. These results are clear indications of the ability of Mo to improve the resistance of the Ni-based steam reforming catalyst to coking. In order to improve coking resistance of the 0.1Mo catalyst and yet sustain its high conversions, the effect of adding small amounts of O2 to the reaction mixture was investigated under otherwise the same reaction conditions. Oxidative steam reforming (OSR) reactions were run for the promoted 0.1Mo and the un-promoted 15Ni catalysts. For both, the reaction temperature was set at 450°C, the S/C ratio was 3, the O2/C ratio was 0.3 and the GHSV was maintained the same by adjusting N2 flow. The reaction was run for 6hours and the conversions for each reaction over each catalyst are compared in Fig. 6 . The improvements in conversion by adding O2 to SR were observed for both catalysts with the effect being more pronounced for the Mo-containing catalyst. Within the first two hours of the experiments, the conversion was 10% higher for OSR than SR over the Mo-containing catalyst and was sustained throughout the run, while it increased only by 2-3% for the Ni catalyst. Moreover, as expected, the addition of O2 improved the stability of the Mo-containing catalyst, as after the run no carbon deposition was observed; the weight of the bed did not change. On the other hand, even with the addition of O2, the un-promoted catalyst still suffered activity loss due to coking. After the OSR test, the Ni catalyst bed weight increased by 11%, with carbon deposition visually observed. The addition of O2 did not have a major effect on H2 production over the Mo-containing catalyst, as it was higher for OSR because of higher conversions, but SR had higher H2 yields as shown in Fig. 7 . CO yields were almost the same for the two reactions over the 0.1Mo sample and like H2, with SR they were higher than the un-promoted catalyst (Fig. 8 ). CH4 also followed the same trend as in the SR reactions with Mo-containing catalysts having lower yields, however, the addition of O2 caused even lower CH4 yields over both catalysts (Fig. 9 ). This was balanced by higher CO2 yields over both catalysts for OSR compared to SR (Fig. 10 ). Moreover, CO2 yields were slightly higher over the Ni catalyst during OSR compared to the Mo-promoted catalyst for the same reaction. These results indicate that the addition of even these small amounts of O2 had a significant effect on improving the stability of the catalyst and preventing coking. Moreover, the presence of O2 affected the selectivity of the Mo-containing catalyst to different products. The differences in activity, selectivity and stability of the Mo-promoted catalyst is a clear indication that the addition of even these small amounts of Mo had an effect on the Ni-based catalyst, in addition, this effect is highly sensitive to the amount of Mo loading as even a slight increase from 0.1 to 0.5 lowered the conversion of the catalyst by about 30%; however, increasing the Mo loading prevented catalyst coking. 3.2 Characterization of the samples with addition of Mo to the Ni/Al2O3catalyst The interactions between Mo and Ni and the support were characterized to explain the effect of Mo on the activity, selectivity and stability of the promoted Ni catalyst. A significant challenge was the low loading of Mo, as most characterization methods were expected to fail in detecting such small amounts or different phases related to them. However, any change in the Ni or Al2O3 structure due to the addition of Mo was interpreted by comparing the un-promoted with promoted catalysts with different Mo loadings. 3.2.1 Temperature Programmed Reduction (TPR) The interaction between the Al2O3 support and different Ni phases is an important factor in controlling Ni reducibility. Although a strong metal support interaction will result in a lower degree of Ni reducibility, this strong interaction may affect the electronic properties of Ni or Al2O3 resulting in different product selectivities, or improving the catalyst resistance to different types of deactivation. TPR experiments were used to investigate the effect of Mo addition on the interactions between Ni and Al2O3. In addition to running TPR for the three catalysts; 15Ni/Al2O3 (15Ni), 0.1Mo-15Ni/Al2O3 (0.1Mo), and 0.5Mo–15Ni/Al2O3 (0.5Mo), TPR was also run for a 1wt.% Mo–15% wt.Ni/Al2O3 (1Mo) catalyst prepared and pre-treated in the same way as the other three catalysts. Although this catalyst was inactive under reaction conditions used, TPR was run to magnify changes resulting from reduction of different MoOx species, especially for the 0.5Mo catalyst. Fig. 11 shows the change in H2 consumption with temperature recorded during TPR measurements for the four catalysts. H2 consumption for the non-promoted Ni catalyst began at 422°C, this first increase in H2 consumption is attributed to the reduction of bulk NiO which is not, or is weakly, interacting with the alumina support. Unsupported bulk NiO is known to reduce to atomic Ni0 in the 200–450°C range, however, the introduction of the support increases this temperature range to around 500°C [30,33,34]. At 510°C, the evolution of another peak was observed, hitting a maximum at 620°C and ending at 665°C. This reduction stage covers a range of NiO species which are strongly interacting with the support; NiO-Al2O3. These strong NiO-Al2O3 interactions are caused by the dissolution and incorporation of Al3+ ions in NiO crystallites which makes the disruption of the Ni-O bond difficult [33]. This process is more favorable at high calcination temperatures and lower Ni loadings. In addition, the high surface area γ-Al2O3 support increases the reduction temperature due to its interaction with H2O vapor formed during NiO reduction [23,24]. At 690°C a broad peak is observed for the 15Ni catalyst, reaching a maximum at 845°C, and is still evident to the end of the run at 950°C. This broad, high temperature reduction peak is associated with strongly dispersed spinel-like NiAl2O4 species which begin to form at calcination temperatures above 500°C (as proved from XRD analysis presented in the next section). It is clear that the 700°C calcination temperature of the 15Ni catalysts caused strong support/metal oxide interactions leading to higher reduction temperatures. However, it should be pointed out that the strong alumina/NiO interaction plays an important role in preventing the deactivation of the Ni catalyst via fouling and sintering. It was reported by Bengaard et al. [35] that during CH4 steam reforming over Ni catalysts, both the reforming reaction and the formation of carbon are initiated at the same type of active site, which they attributed to defect step sites. The steam reforming reaction requires a Ni ensemble of only 3 or 4 atoms, while an ensemble of 6 or 7 Ni atoms is required to form a reactive surface carbon intermediate which acts as a precursor for different carbon types [36,37]. Strong interactions between alumina and NiO favor the formation of small NiO clusters, which enhances Ni dispersion and prevents the formation of large Ni ensembles during the course of the reaction [5]. Moreover, the formation of a solid solution between alumina and Ni at high calcination temperatures will suppress aggregation and sintering of the metal at high reaction temperatures, and hence improves its thermal stability [38,39]. The addition of 0.1Mo did not induce a significant change in the TPR trends compared to the 15Ni catalyst. The 0.1Mo data in Fig. 11 have the same three reduction peaks described earlier. However, the onset of the first reduction peak was slightly lower and the NiO-Al2O3 interaction peak was broader and covered a temperature range from 488 to 700°C. Overall, reduction temperatures are slightly shifted to lower temperatures indicating that Mo might have affected the strength of the NiO-Al2O3 interaction. In the analysis of the TPR trends for the 0.5Mo catalyst, the three Ni reduction peaks can still be identified, in addition to smaller peaks related to the reduction of different phases of MoOx [30]. These small peaks are clearer in the 1Mo TPR data, and could be identified on a similarity basis in Fig. 11. Bulk NiO was reduced between 388 and 432°C for the 0.5Mo catalyst while for the 1Mo catalyst, the range was 361 to 461°C. For the Mo catalysts, it is hard to determine the exact range of the NiO-Al2O3 peak as some phases of MoOx reduce in the same range. However peak maxima for the NiO-Al2O3 phase can be identified for the 0.5Mo catalyst at 575°C, and for the 1Mo catalyst at 553°C, as these peaks were also shifted to lower temperatures with the addition of Mo. As the ramped temperature increased beyond the NiO-Al2O3 reduction range, for both catalysts (0.5Mo and 1Mo), H2 consumption increased at different rates creating a series of small peaks and reaching maxima at 823 and 795°C for the 0.5Mo and the 1Mo catalysts, respectively. At these temperatures, NiAl2O4 is reduced together with different MoOx phases [23,24,40,41]. Bulk MoO3 is difficult to reduce and requires high temperatures to ensure a full reduction to metallic Mo0. TPR profiles of bulk MoO3 reveals two reduction peaks; the first in the 750–800°C range is attributed to the reduction of MoO3 to MoO2, with a second occurring at 950–1000°C resulting from the reduction of MoO2 to metallic Mo [42]. When MoO3 is supported on Al2O3, two peaks are observed at lower temperatures. With the first peak, occurring at 400–450°C, polymeric structures of MoO3 are reduced to MoO2 while further reduction to Mo0 is shifted to lower temperatures, 700–950°C, with bulk MoO3 reducing between the two ranges [23,24,40,41]. Addition of Ni to Mo was found to lower MoOx reduction temperatures. In their TPR analysis of a Ni-Mo desulphurization catalyst, Brito and Laine [43] found that NiO and MoOx reduced independently when calcined at low temperatures (400–600°C). However, they also found that each phase accelerates the reduction of the other. For NiO this is in agreement with our results as the addition of Mo weakened the NiO-Al2O3 interactions causing its reduction to shift to lower temperatures. In the TPR profile of 1Mo in Fig. 11, the series of small peaks in the NiO-Al2O3 peak occurring between 450 and 515°C could be attributed to the reduction of dispersed polymeric structures of MoO3 to MoO2, while small peaks at higher temperatures, 600–800°C, are assigned to further reduction of these phases to Mo0 [27]. A series of small peaks at relatively high temperatures in the range 830–950°C were observed for both 0.5Mo and 1Mo. Due to the small amounts of Mo it is hard to assign these small peaks to particular phases or compounds. However, some speculation can be made based on the literature. The series of peaks at high temperatures could be attributed to the reduction of three-phase component interactions NiO-Al2O3-MoO3 which can be formed even in the presence of very small amounts of promoters (Mo:Ni ratios of 0.03–0.06) [23,24,44]. In addition to these three-phase components, direct interaction between NiO and MoOx induced by the high calcination temperatures when pre-treating the Ni-Mo catalysts could form a NiMoO4 phase [29,30]. The reduction of NiMoO4 takes place in stages and, depending on the reduction temperature and environment, could result in the formation of NixMo compounds or Ni-Mo alloys and MoO2 which are difficult to reduce. Therefore, in many cases formation of bulky NiMoO4 will result in poor reducibility of the Ni catalyst and the loss of Ni active sites due to the decoration of these sites by different MoOx species [30]. Moreover, the formation of the difficult-to-reduce phases in Ni-Mo catalysts is highly affected by the impregnating sequence of the two metals at the catalyst preparation stage. It has been reported in the literature that Ni-Mo catalysts prepared by co-impregnation or co-precipitation of the metals favors the formation of NiMoO4 over sequential impregnation with Mo first [45,46]. Therefore, in our case we expect the formation of NiMoO4 even at small Mo:Ni ratios. However, it should be pointed out that contrary to our lower reduction temperatures with the addition of Mo, TPR results in a few studies that sequentially impregnated Mo on Ni/Al2O3 catalysts showed that even small amounts of Mo shifted different NiO reduction peaks to higher temperatures [23,24,27,37]. The increase in the reduction temperature of sequentially impregnated catalysts was attributed to stronger interactions between MoO3 and NiO due to decoration of NiO with MoO3, which led to the formation of a NiO-MoO3 hard-to-reduce solid solution. On the other hand, when Ni was impregnated on a MoO3/Al2O3 catalyst, TPR profiles were the same as the non-promoted Ni/Al2O3 catalyst [37] or slightly shifted to higher temperatures [23,24]. Therefore, since such low Mo loadings (0.1–0.5wt.%) on our co-impregnated Ni-Mo/Al2O3 catalyst shifted the reduction temperature of the Ni/Al2O3 catalysts to lower temperatures, we do not expect that changes of the catalyst properties are related to textural effects. 3.2.2 X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements Due to our low Mo loadings, identification of chemical phases related to Mo, MoOx or even of NiMoO4 are not expected. However, a change in Ni crystallinity of the promoted catalyst may indicate a minor textural effect of the promoter on the Ni based catalyst. XRD measurements were taken for reduced and calcined catalysts pre-treated with the same methods used for the catalyst activity tests. In addition to the three catalysts, XRD patterns were measured for pure γ-Al2O3support that was also calcined at the same conditions, in order to distinguish patterns related to the support. The XRD patterns are not shown for brevity but are discussed here. As expected, no patterns were detected for any Mo-related phases [47]. And even at higher Mo loadings it would have been difficult to detect some phases, such as MoO2 and NiMoO4, as their diffraction patterns overlap the higher intensity NiO and Al2O3 patterns. All three calcined catalyst showed three distinguishable NiO patterns, related to NiO (111) at 2θ =36.5°, NiO (200) at 2θ =43.8° and a much smaller one NiO (220) at 2θ =63.3°. When reducing the catalysts, NiO patterns disappeared, indicating reduction of these phases. In addition, three patterns for metallic Ni were identified: Ni(111), Ni(200) and Ni(220). Small and broad Ni patterns may be a result of highly incorporated Ni in the support which indicates Ni-Al2O3 interactions as illustrated in the TPR results. When comparing patterns of the three reduced catalysts, the 0.5Mo catalyst showed slightly smaller intensities, which may indicate lower amounts of reduced Ni [47]. The calcined support showed three distinguish Al2O3patterns: Al2O3(311), Al2O3(400) and Al2O3(440). When comparing the location of Al2O3(440) in the reduced and the calcined catalysts, a slight shift in the Al2O3(440) angle could be observed from 67.2° to 66.8°. This slight decrease in the Al2O3(440) angle with the addition of Ni indicates the formation of a NiAl2O3 spinel structure, as the incorporation of Ni in the Al2O3 structure causes an increase in the lattice parameters, due to the greater ionic radius of Ni2+ compared to Al3+ [5,30,48]. In general, XRD patterns did not show significant differences between the promoted and the un-promoted catalysts that could be attributed to changes in the crystallinity of the catalyst. 3.2.3 H2 chemisorption measurements H2 chemisorption was used to investigate the effect of Mo on the distribution of active Ni sites, which will in turn indicate if Mo has a textural effect on the Ni catalyst. H2 chemisorption was measured for three reduced catalysts (15Ni, 0.1Mo and 0.5Mo). During chemisorption it was assumed that Mo does not adsorb any H2 even in the presence of Ni and all results are attributed to Ni dispersion over the support. This is justified by the small Mo loadings in the promoted catalyst, and also because it has been reported in the literature that a 1wt.% MoO3/Al2O3 catalyst did not chemisorb any H2 [27,49]. The data showed that the Ni dispersion was the same on all three catalysts (around 9.5%) and therefore, Mo did not have any significant effect on Ni dispersion, which is consistent with the XRD results. These XRD and H2 chemisorption results indicate that these small Mo loadings do not have significant textural effects on the Ni catalyst that could explain the changes in the catalytic properties of the Ni catalyst. 3.2.4 Oxygen Storage Capacity (OSC) measurements The small amounts of O2 introduced in propane SR had a significant effect on improving the stability of the catalyst and preventing coking. Moreover, the presence of O2 affected the selectivity of the Mo catalyst to different products. These observations could indicate that the addition of Mo, even in these small quantities, improved the mobility of oxygen on the catalyst surface. To evaluate this, oxygen storage capacity (OSC) was measured for the three catalysts; 15Ni, 0.1Mo and 0.5Mo at room temperature and at 400°C. O2 uptakes at the two temperatures for the three catalysts are presented in Table 2 . The addition of 0.1wt.% Mo to the Ni catalysts increased its O2 uptake by about 300% (3-fold increase) at both RT and 400°C, while increasing the Mo loading to 0.5wt.% caused an increase of O2 uptake by 73% at RT and by 160% at 400°C. The decrease in O2 uptake between room temperature and 400°C was significantly higher for the 15Ni and 0.1Mo catalysts (35 and 37% decrease) compared to only 2% for the 0.5Mo catalyst. This is attributed to the O2 uptake for 0.5Mo at 400°C being not only a result of O2 chemisorption, but also some O2 is consumed in oxidizing Ni to NiO as the TPR measurements (Section 3.2.1) showed that bulk NiO reduction over the 0.5Mo catalyst starts at 388°C while it is above 400°C for the other two catalysts. TPR runs for the 0.5Mo and 1% Mo–15Ni catalysts revealed that Mo can exist in different oxidation states. This was also proven through XPS measurements of a reduced Mo-Ni catalyst by Borowiecki et al. [50], as they indicated the presence of Mo in the forms of Mo+6, Mo0 and Mo+n (4< n <5). The existence of Mo in different oxidation states can facilitate redox properties of Mo-containing catalysts. Indeed, MoO2 was found to be highly active in iso-octane partial oxidation [51]. The high activity was attributed to the ability of MoO2 to provide oxygen, sustaining a redox cycle on the catalyst surface. However, we do not believe that an increase of ca. 300% in OSC for the 0.1Mo catalyst could be attributed to Mo oxidation state cycling alone since at room temperature 80% more O2 was consumed when measuring the OSC of the 0.1Mo catalyst relative to the 0.5Mo catalyst. Furthermore, if that was the case, an increase in the Mo loading to 0.5wt.% should have further increased the OSC, which was actually decreased. Therefore, the increase in OSC by the addition of small amounts of Mo could be attributed to an increase in oxygen ionic conductivity of Ni caused by an electronic interaction between Mo and Ni. This electronic effect allows cycling of Ni0 and Ni+2 depending on the reaction atmosphere, enhancing O2 mobility on the catalyst surface and hence resulting in higher gasification rates of CHx species to CO and H2. Lower OSC at higher 0.5% Mo indicates a decrease in the quantity of Ni particles available for the cycling process although a high O2 mobility is still sustained, as high CO and H2 levels were produced over the 0.5Mo catalyst in SR activity tests. 3.3 In-situ DRIFTS analysis of propane reactions One of the most interesting results from propane SR experiments was the higher CO yields when Ni catalysts were promoted with Mo. Even at lower conversions with the 0.5Mo catalyst, the CO production rates were higher than the 0.1Mo catalyst. These higher CO yields could not be explained by the methanation reaction. Another possibility is that the presence of Mo affects the adsorption of CO. To evaluate this, in-situ Diffusion Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectroscopy (DRIFTS) experiments were used to identify and quantify different adsorbed species on each of the three catalyst surfaces during propane-based reactions. 3.3.1 CO and propane adsorption CO adsorption experiments were run at room temperature with the 15Ni and 0.1Mo catalysts. After flushing with He for 30min, a 5% CO/He stream was introduced and spectra were collected every minute until equilibrium was reached after 12–14min. The CO stream was then shut off and only He was flowed while the desorption spectra were collected. CO adsorption was assumed to take place only on Ni particles, as it was reported in the literature that no CO adsorption was detected on a Mo/Al2O3 catalyst even at 15wt.% Mo loadings [17,52]. Only two bands, at 2117 and 2175cm−1, were detected, and had the same absorbance for both catalysts (data not shown for brevity). These bands are related to gaseous CO and disappeared after switching off the CO, indicating only physical adsorption of CO on both catalysts at room temperature. Propane adsorption experiments were run following the same procedure as in CO adsorption using a stream of 2% propane/He. Fig. 12 shows spectra of propane adsorption at the 15th min for the two catalysts. The absorbance band at 2966cm−1 is attributed to gaseous propane [53]. This band overlaps bands 2940–2930cm−1 which are assigned to asymmetric methyl (ν asCH3) and methene (ν asCH2) stretching, and bands around 2860cm−1 assigned to symmetric methyl (ν sCH3) and methene (ν sCH2) stretching [15,53,54]. Bands at lower wavenumbers; 1473 and 1388cm−1 could be attributed to asymmetric methyl (δ asCH3) and symmetric methyl (δ sCH3), respectively. All these bands were detected on both catalysts. However all the bands disappeared when switching to He for desorption, indicating weak/physical adsorption only. 3.3.2 In-situ DRIFTS analysis during propane partial oxidation (PO) Propane PO in-situ DRIFTS experiments were run at 390°C for the three catalysts; 15Ni, 0.1Mo and 0.5Mo. The cell temperature was raised to 390°C under a flow of He and was kept at these conditions for 30–45min until a stable background signal was obtained. Then a stream of 1.2% propane, 1.62% O2 and He was introduced, with an O2/C of 4.5. Spectra were collected every minute until no change in the signal was observed, occurring after about 12–14min. The reaction mixture stream was then closed and only He flowed while the desorption spectra were collected. Fig. 13 shows the adsorption spectra for the three catalysts at the 3rd, 5th, and 15th min (once steady-state was reached). At all three times a distinguishable difference between the three catalysts was observed for the bands ranging from 1760 to 2094cm−1, which are attributed to molecular CO adsorption. Bands in the 2100–2000cm−1 region are assigned to linear CO adsorption, which is favored over isolated metal sites (corners and edges), while bands in the 1900–1800cm−1 range are most likely a contribution of bridging CO, adsorbed on more flat and extensive metal sites [53,55,56]. For the 15Ni and the 0.1Mo catalysts, within the first 5min of the reaction, CO was adsorbed more on the less reactive flat sites. As the conversion increased, with time Ni surface ensembles change to smaller islands with more active edge sites, enhancing the linear adsorption of CO. This change is based on the increase in the amount of linearly adsorbed CO and a decrease in bridging CO [53,55,56]. It was reported in the literature that CO adsorbs dissociatively on transition metals of the upper left corner of the periodic table and molecularly on transition metals on the lower right corner [35]. Since Ni is located close to the border of the two groups, CO is expected to adsorb on Ni in both modes depending on the surface structure of the catalysts and its temperature. It was found that CO adsorbed molecularly over Ni at RT and begins to desorb at 177°C [35]. Therefore, we speculate that the high CO production over the 0.1Mo and 0.5Mo catalysts observed in the activity experiments is a result of weak adsorption or rapid desorption of CO in the presence of the small amounts of Mo. The data therefore suggest that Mo changed the Ni surface, electronic not textural, due to the small amount of Mo compared to relatively large changes in CO adsorption bands (and XRD and dispersion results). The differences in linear and bridged adsorbed CO bands between the three catalysts were sustained when the reacting flow was turned off and only He was flowing as the desorption spectra were collected (see Fig. 14 ). CO bands for the 15Ni catalysts were detected even after 15min desorption, while the 0.1Mo catalysts only showed the bridging CO band with a much smaller linear CO band after 10min of desorption. On the other hand, the 0.5Mo catalyst lost both of its CO bands after 3min of desorption. CO adsorption and dissociation over Ni is not only structure sensitive, but also affected by the presence of H2 in the reaction environment [57]. It was found that in the presence of H2, chemisorbed CO can be rapidly displaced from the Ni surface by H2 which will cause CO desorption at lower temperatures [58–60]. Likewise, CO dissociation follows a different route when H2 is present, as it dissociates through a CHO intermediate rather than a direct route in the absence of H2 [57]. The formation of CHO intermediates was not only reported for the CO dissociation reactions, but also was suggested by a number of authors to be an intermediate in the formation of adsorbed CO during SR and PO reactions rather than the direct reaction between gaseous carbon and adsorbed oxygen to form CO [61,62]. In either case, higher H2 production over the 0.1Mo and 0.5Mo catalysts could be due to more rapid CO desorption. Higher CO production over the Mo-promoted catalysts was not clearly distinguishable from the features associated with gaseous CO, in the 2100 to 2250cm−1 range, however, CO gaseous bands were detected by the 3rd min for the 0.5Mo catalyst while the spectra obtained with the two other catalysts did not show any bands by that time (see Fig. 13). Bands in the range 2200–2400cm−1 are assigned to gaseous CO2, with the 0.5Mo catalyst band having the lowest absorbance due to lower CO2 production, which is in agreement with the catalyst activity experiments. These gaseous CO2 bands disappeared rapidly after switching to the desorption mode. As illustrated earlier in the propane DRIFTS experiments, the peak at 2966cm−1 was attributed to gaseous propane and it overlaps bands in the range 2860–2940cm−1 which are assigned to different symmetric and asymmetric CH3 and CH2 stretching features. These bands had different absorbance intensities for the three catalysts, higher for the 0.5Mo and 0.1Mo catalysts than the 15Ni. The higher intensity for the 0.5Mo band could be argued to be a result of more gaseous propane due to lower conversion. However, our catalyst activity tests showed that the conversion over 0.1Mo and 15Ni are almost the same, yet there is a significant difference in the intensities of these bands. Therefore we speculate that this difference is attributed to more CH3 and CH2 adsorbed on the surface of the Mo catalysts than over the Ni catalyst. For the un-promoted Ni catalyst, CH2 and CH3 are unstable and tend to dehydrogenate rapidly to more stable carbon which in turn contributes to catalyst deactivation. Due to its instability, CH3 can also react with adsorbed hydrogen to form CH4, which was produced in smaller quantities over the Mo-containing catalysts in the activity experiments. Therefore the role of Mo in preventing coking of the Ni catalyst could be attributed to preventing the complete dehydrogenation of CHx to carbon species, and directly oxidizing these species to CO and H2 instead. Consequently, lower CH4 production rates over the Mo-promoted catalysts were observed in activity tests. From another perspective, as mentioned earlier, the formation of CO was argued by a number of authors to result through the reactions: (R4) CHx*+OH*=CHxO*+H* (R5) CHxO*+H*=CO+H2 where * is an adsorption site on the catalyst surface, rather than the direct reaction: (R6) Cα*+O*=CO** Therefore, more CHx adsorbed species could result in higher CO production. Adsorbed OH bands appear in the 3500–3750cm−1 range for all three catalysts [15,56]. The intensities for the bands were higher for the Mo-containing catalysts than for the non-promoted sample, indicating that more OH was available on the Mo-containing catalyst for CHx gasification to CO, and could promote the OH gasification route rather than through O only, even if carbon was formed on the Ni catalyst. Smaller bands at 1300–1390cm−1 are attributed to symmetric monodentate carbonates (ν sCOO−) while bands at 1470–1530cm−1 are assigned to asymmetric monodentate carbonates (ν asCOO−) [53]. Asymmetric (δ asCH3) and symmetric (δ sCH3) methyl species can also co-exist in these two ranges. Bidentate carbonates are represented by bands in the 1530–1620cm−1 range, however, these bands can also be attributed to olefinic CC vibrations, 1580–1660cm−1 [53,63]. The band at 3020cm−1 is also assigned to olefinic sp2 C–H stretching and therefore bands at 1590cm−1 are more likely to be attributed to olefinic CC, initiating the formation of ethylene or propylene. All these bands were lower in intensity for the 0.5Mo catalyst due to its lower conversion. 3.3.3 In-situ drifts analysis for propane steam reforming (SR) Propane SR in-situ DRIFTS experiments were run with the 15Ni, 0.1Mo and 0.5Mo catalysts at 390°C. The cell temperature was raised to 390°C under a flow of He that passed through liquid water, saturating the gas stream. The background signal was subtracted under the He and steam flow at 390°C. SR experiments were started by introducing a stream of 1.15% propane with the He/steam stream. Assuming a maximum water vapor saturation of 2–3%, the S/C ratio was in the range 0.6–0.9. Spectra were collected every minute until no change in the signal was observed after 12–14min. The spectra at the 3rd, 5th and 15th minute are shown in Fig. 15 , respectively. Due to the presence of steam the spectra showed higher noise; however, the spectra for the three catalysts had the same features as those of the PO spectra. The linear and bridging CO features were larger for the Ni catalyst and lower on 0.5Mo while CH3 and CH2 species were of opposite trend. CO adsorption has been alluded to for Ni-Mo and Co-Mo catalysts during steam reforming in the literature [24,27,64,65]. CO2 gaseous bands were higher for 0.1Mo than the 15Ni due to higher conversions, which is in agreement with the activity experiments. Since the background signal was subtracted in the presence of steam, OH bands from H2O dissociation were not detected: however, a negative OH band at 3560cm−1 was clear in the spectra obtained from the 0.1Mo and 0.5Mo catalysts, which could be attributed to surface hydroxyl groups on the alumina support consumed upon the adsorption of, or reaction with, propane [15]. In general, similar results regarding CO and CHx species are observed for PO and SR DRIFTS experiments. 3.4 Interpretation of characterization results The results of the different characterization techniques point towards the small amount of Mo definitely impacting Ni's catalytic properties. TPR data for the 15Ni catalysts showed that the high calcination temperature when pre-treating the catalyst caused relatively strong interactions between NiO and the alumina support. γ-Al2O3 can be a Brønsted proton donor acid due to surface hydroxyl groups and a Lewis acid electron acceptor at dehydrated aluminum sites. This moderate acidity has a crucial role in reactions involving acid sites; one of these reactions is hydrocarbon cracking which is also the major cause of Ni steam reforming catalyst deactivation. When γ-Al2O3 is impregnated with Ni, the bivalent metal cation occupies tetrahedral sites in the spinel structure [66], leading to a decrease in the cationic deficiency of γ-Al2O3 and hence, lowering its Lewis acidity and stabilizing the structure. The interaction between NiO and γ-Al2O3 also plays a physical role in reducing carbon formation, as it favors the formation of small NiO clusters, where larger Ni ensembles favor the initiation of carbon formation. Even with these Ni properties, coking of Ni/γ-Al2O3 could not be avoided. A negative effect of strong interactions between Ni and alumina is that in an oxidative environment, Ni can be oxidized to form spinel NiAl2O4, which can begin to form at temperatures as low as 400°C. NiAl2O4 is inactive in SR, and TPR runs showed that it requires temperatures as high as 800°C to be reduced. Therefore, although O2 facilitates the gasification of carbon, high ratios may cause the loss of Ni sites by oxidation to NiO or NiAl2O4. However, it should be noted that in the absence of O2, the oxidation of Ni to NiO has not been observed in the presence of steam only, even at temperatures as high as 700°C [23,24]. With the 0.1Mo catalyst, reduction of NiO was shifted to lower temperatures and more Ni was present as NiO rather than NiAl2O4, indicating that Mo weakened the NiO-γ-Al2O3 interactions. This led to a higher degree of Ni reduction as supported by the higher OSC of the 0.1Mo catalyst. We speculate that the effect of Mo on the metal support interaction strength is due to an electronegativity influence of Mo on Ni. Mo has an electronegativity of 2.16 on the Pauling scale while the electronegativity of Ni is 1.91, so Mo is a better electron acceptor. Moreover, MoOx is considered to be a strong Lewis acid while NiO is a mild base. It is expected that at higher Mo loadings, MoO3 and MoO2 are the two main oxides that exist on the promoted catalysts, and as the catalyst is further reduced, more MoO2 is present [23,27]. MoO2 has a higher electrical conductivity due to its higher density of state in the valence region and more free electrons, compared to MoO3 where all neighbouring oxygen atoms form a covalent bond with Mo [67]. As Mo phases are imbedded in the Ni catalyst, these electronic properties affect the electronic state of Ni species, leading to a lower charge transfer between Ni and γ-Al2O3 acid sites, and hence, impeding the incorporation of the Ni species in the alumina lattice. As Ni is less incorporated in γ-Al2O3, it will be easier to reduce and perhaps to oxidize at lower temperatures. Therefore, we expect Ni to be oxidized and reduced under our reaction conditions. This redox cycling will not only depend on the oxidative and reductive agents present in the reaction atmosphere, but also on different oxidation states of MoOx species. Such redox cycling would improve oxygen ion-conductivity through the Ni, enhancing the mobility of oxygen on the catalyst surface and hence the gasification of CHx species. The change in the electronic state of Ni species will also affect the stability of adsorbed reaction intermediates on the surface. Based on DFT calculations, Bengaard et al. [35] reported that during the dissociative chemisorption of CH4 to different CHx species, adsorbed gaseous carbon (*C) is the most stable intermediate on Ni(211) step sites, compared to less stable CH3 and CH2 intermediates. Therefore, non-promoted Ni favors the complete dehydrogenation of CHx species to *C which can initiate the formation of more difficult to gasify forms of carbon. On the other hand, in-situ DRIFTS experiments for propane PO and SR showed that there were more CH3 and CH2 adsorbed species over the 0.1Mo and 0.5Mo catalysts than 15Ni. We expect that the electronic change in Ni led to more stable adsorbed CHx species and prevented their further dehydration to carbon. CHx species are more active than gaseous carbon and can be readily gasified by the mobile oxygen available on the surface to CO and H2. Furthermore, the in-situ DRIFTS experiments indicated less, or weaker, CO adsorption on the Mo-promoted catalysts. Therefore, although the O2 mobility was improved over the catalyst surface, the oxidation of CO to CO2 was not also enhanced due, adsorbed CO being relatively unstable. With increasing loading, Mo would have a greater electronic effect on the Ni. These effects led to lower NiO reduction temperatures indicating weaker NiO-γ-Al2O3 interactions and hence, again less Ni incorporated in the alumina lattice. As a result, Ni can more easily undergo redox cycling during the reaction. It is also expected that with higher Mo loadings, MoOx can contribute to oxygen ion conductivity. TPR experiments for 0.5Mo and 1Mo catalysts showed that MoOx exists in different oxidation states, and are reduced at lower temperatures in the presence of Ni. Similar conclusions were drawn using XPS measurements of a reduced Mo-Ni catalyst [50], where the authors suggested the presence of Mo as Mo+6, Mo0 and Mo+n (4< n <5). Therefore, MoOx species can also undergo redox cycling during the course of the reaction, contributing to oxygen mobility on the catalyst surface and preventing coking. This higher oxygen ion conductivity indeed resulted in higher CO and H2 yields over 0.5Mo than 0.1Mo as proved by SR activity runs in Section 3.1. However, propane SR activity runs showed lower conversions for the 0.5Mo catalyst. This was attributed to the loss of Ni sites due to the decoration of Ni or NiO by MoOx, or by the formation of difficult-to-reduce NiMoO4, which can occur at the catalyst preparation stage as proven via TPR. Therefore, although we expect that the oxygen ion conductivity of 0.5Mo is higher than 0.1Mo, the density of the oxygen conductors is lower, also suggested by OSC measurements. Consequently, optimizing the Mo loading in the Ni-Mo catalyst is a matter of finding the right ratio of the ion conductivity strength to the density of conductors. 3.5 Effects of Mo on the general propane OSR reaction scheme The mechanism of CH4 steam reforming has been extensively studied, however, less research has focused on propane and higher hydrocarbon steam reforming mechanisms. Generally, PO and SR reactions for higher hydrocarbons will proceed through the dissociative adsorption of the hydrocarbon, in this case propane. The adsorbed hydrocarbons dissociate into CHx species, which can dehydrogenate to produce H2 and C, that can be gasified by adsorbed oxygen to CO and CO2. Adsorbed oxygen is produced from the dissociation of O2 or H2O: (R7) O2 +2*↔2O* (R8) H2O+*↔O*+H2 (R9) H2 +2*↔2H* (R10) O*2H*↔OH*+H* Although this work does not present any evidence that Mo has an effect on H2O dissociation, enhanced O2 mobility on the catalyst can assist H2O dissociation, as it was reported that adsorbed oxygen species auto-catalyze H2O dissociation [68]. However, higher levels of oxygen will slow the process due to the occupation of Ni sites by oxygen. In the presence of O or OH, propane is adsorbed on the catalyst to produce a propyl group. The propyl group may result from adsorption on a primary carbon: (R11) CH3CH2CH3 +2*→CH3CH2CH2*+H* or a secondary carbon: (R12) CH3CH2CH3 +2*→CH3CH*CH2 +H* If the propyl group was adsorbed on a secondary carbon it will result in the formation of propylene: (R13) CH3CH*CH2 +H*→C3H6 +2*+H2 Statistically, the propyl group is more likely to adsorb on a primary carbon [1]. This agrees with our results, as propylene was detected only for the 15Ni catalyst, and in very small amounts compared to acetylene and ethane. Adsorption of propyl on a primary carbon will result in an ethyl group and a methyl group: (R14) CH3CH2CH2*+H*→CH3CH2*+CH3* Over some metal catalysts, such as Rh, propyl groups are more likely to undergo an α-hydrogen elimination [1]. This leads to rapid dehydrogenation of propyl to produce more H2 and Cα* with no or lower by-product hydrocarbons i.e. ethane, ethylene, methane, etc. This path was also suggested by Natesakhawatet al. [15] based on their DRIFTS experiments of propane SR over a sol–gel Ni-Ce/Al2O3 catalyst. However, in our case, since on both types of catalysts, Ni and Mo-Ni, a significant amount of CH4 together with traces of by-product hydrocarbons were detected especially during SR reactions, propyl is more likely to undergo a β-elimination. Therefore, ethyl and methyl species may further react with an adsorbed H* to produce ethane and methane, respectively through hydrogenolysis: (R15) CH3CH2*+H*↔CH3CH3 +2* (R16) CH3 +H*↔CH4 +2* However, steam reforming activity experiments showed less CH4 production over the Mo-containing catalysts compared to Ni, and in addition, in-situ propane SR DRIFTS experiments showed more adsorbed CHx species on the Mo-containing catalyst surface. Therefore, we speculate that Reaction (R16) is less favorable in the presence of Mo. The lesser CH4 production in the presence of Mo is in agreement with results from the work of Boroweicki et al. [50], where they studied butane hydrogenolysis over different Mo-Ni catalysts at low temperatures (240–260°C) and found that CH4 selectivity was lower with the addition of Mo to the Ni catalysts. They also found that CH4 selectivity decreased as they increased the Mo loading from 0.1 to 4%wt. They concluded from these results that the introduction of Mo caused a change in the properties of the active centers on the catalyst surface. With methyl groups not converted to CH4, they will further dehydrogenate to CHx, producing more H* and ultimately also α carbon (Cα*): (R17) CH3*+6*↔3H*+Cα* Which can be gasified directly by O* to CO**: (R18) Cα*+O*→CO** Or by OH* first to CHO** then to CO** [69]: (R19) Cα*+OH*↔CHO** (R20) CHO**+3*→CO**+H*+2* The complete dehydrogenation of CHx as it appears in Reaction (R17) and the gasification of Cα* to CO** (R18) has been discussed in the literature. Bradford and Vannice [62] argued that the reaction of CHx* with OH* to form a CHxO* intermediate is more likely to occur than the reaction of OH* with Cα* to form CHO** since CHx* species are more reactive than gaseous Cα*: (R21) CHx*+OH*↔CHxO*+H* (R22) CHxO*+H*→CO*+H2 This was also suggested by Rostrup-Neilsen and Hansen [61] as they postulated the reaction of CHx* with adsorbed O* rather than OH* to produce CO* and H*. (R23) CHx*+O*→CO*+H2 +2 The ethyl groups not converted to ethane can further undergo α-elimination: (R24) CH3CH2*+2*↔CH3CH**+H* This can result in rapid dehydrogenation of the intermediates to ultimately produce H2 and adsorbed gaseous carbon *Cα. Or a β-elimination can occur: (R25) CH3CH2*+2*↔CH2*CH2*+H* Where the intermediate can then further desorb to produce ethylene [1]: (R26) CH2*CH2*↔CH2CH2 +2* However, when studying chemisorption and decomposition of ethylene over Ni catalysts, Zaera and Hall [70] found that unlike Pt and Pd, once dehydrogenated intermediates are formed on Ni they are difficult to desorb resulting in further dehydrogenation of these intermediates. They also found that the further decomposition of chemisorbed vinyl over Ni can result in the formation of acetylene. Since no ethylene was detected in our OSR and SR experiments, the CH2*CH2* intermediate must further dehydrogenate to produce an adsorbed vinyl group, which further dehydrogenates to form acetylene (R27), as traces of acetylene were detected for both Ni and Ni-Mo catalysts: (R27) CH2*CH2*↔CHCH+2*+2H2 However, since only small traces of acetylene and ethane were detected over the 0.1Mo catalyst during OSR, compared to the other four main products; H2, CO, CO2 and CH4, only a very small portion of ethyl species in Reaction (R25) will follow the path to produce acetylene or ethane. Most of the ethyl species in Reaction (R25) will further undergo dissociative adsorption to fragments of methyl CH3 and methylene CH2 which will follow different routes suggested earlier to produce H* and CO*: (R28) CH3CH2 +2*↔CH2**+CH3* Adsorbed CO** can further react with adsorbed oxygen O* to produce CO2: (R29) CO**+O*↔CO2 +3* Over the 0.5Mo catalyst, CO yields during SR were significantly higher than 15Ni and 0.1Mo, with the lowest CO2 yield among the three catalysts. Considering the high CO production over the 0.5Mo catalyst, in-situ DRIFTS experiments for propane SR and PO indicated less CO adsorbed on 0.5Mo. Therefore, we speculate that in the presence of Mo, CO desorbed quickly thus lowering the production of CO2: (R30) CO**↔CO+2* 4 Conclusions The results of this study demonstrate that the addition of small amounts of Mo had a significant effect on the stability of a Ni-based catalyst, preventing coking during propane SR. Moreover, the presence of O2 affected the selectivity of the Mo catalyst to different products. The differences in activity, selectivity and stability of the Mo-promoted is highly sensitive to the amount of Mo loading as even a slight increase from 0.1 to 0.5 lowered the conversion of the catalyst by about 30%, however, increasing the Mo loading prevented catalyst coking. Characterization techniques revealed that the improvements observed in stability and selectivity were caused by an electronic effect of Mo and its different oxide phases on Ni species. The changes in the electronic state of Ni species affected the catalyst properties in two ways: (1) The Ni-Al2O3 interactions were weakened leading to more reducible Ni and easier to reduce and oxidize (redox) Ni species under the reaction conditions. This redox cycling of Ni species improved their oxygen ion conductivity, enhancing the mobility of O2 on the catalyst surface and hence the gasification of CHx species. Higher CHx gasification rates prevented coking of the catalyst and increased H2 and CO production rates. (2) The stability of adsorbed reaction intermediates on the catalysts surface were changed. Mo led to more stable adsorbed CHx species and prevented their further dehydrogenation to carbon. CHx species are more active than gaseous carbon and can be gasified to CO and H2 by the mobile O available on the surface. On the other hand, less stable adsorbed CO was also observed. These changes in intermediate species stabilities impact pathways in the propane OSR mechanism. Weak adsorption of CO lowered its further oxidation to CO2, while faster oxidation of CHx species lowered their hydrogenation to CH4. coredata.dc:description: The effect of promoting a 15wt.% Ni/Al2O3 catalyst with small amounts of Mo (0.1 and 0.5wt.%) to produce H2 via propane oxidative steam reforming was investigated. Activity and stability experiments run at 450°C showed that the 0.1wt.% Mo-promoted catalyst had higher propane conversion, higher H2 yields and showed superior performance in terms of resisting deactivation by coking. Different characterization techniques show that the impact on activity, selectivity and stability are driven by an electronic effect of Mo on Ni, even with such small amounts. For example, oxygen storage capacity measurements revealed higher oxygen mobility over the promoted catalyst surface. This high O2 mobility led to higher gasification rates of carbonaceous species, leading to higher H2 yields and preventing coking of the catalyst. In-situ DRIFTS experiments also showed that the addition of Mo affected the stability of adsorbed reaction intermediates on the catalyst surface. Higher CO yields over the Mo-promoted catalyst resulted from weak adsorption or rapid desorption of CO in the presence of these small amounts of Mo. These changes in intermediate species stabilities affected some pathways in the general propane oxidative steam reforming scheme. Weak adsorption of CO also decreased the amount further oxidized to CO2 while the increased oxidation of CHx species lowered the amount hydrogenated to CH4.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of interactions between Ni and Mo on catalytic properties of a bimetallic Ni-Mo/Al2O3 propane reforming catalyst
